scopy.fingerprint.daylight module¶

Created on Tue Sep 3 09:53:13 2019

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China， @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

class scopy.fingerprint.daylight.Daylight(minPath, maxPath, nBits)[source]¶

Bases: object

a Daylight-like fingerprint based on hashing molecular subgraphs

minPath: int(optional, default:1)

minimum number of bonds to include in the subgraphs

maxPath: int(optional, default:7)

maximum number of bonds to include in the subgraphs

nBits: int(optional, default:2048)

number of bits in the fingerprint

CalculateDaylight(mol)[source]¶

mol: rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

fp: list

scopy.fingerprint.efg module¶

Created on Tue Sep 3 10:31:34 2019

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China， @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

♥I love Princess Zelda forever♥

class scopy.fingerprint.efg.EFG(counter)[source]¶

Bases: object

classification system termed “extended functional groups” (EFG), which are an extension of a set previously used by the CheckMol software, that covers in addition heterocyclic compound classes and periodic table groups. 583 bits

Salmina, Elena, Norbert Haider, and Igor Tetko. Molecules, 21(1), 1.

counter: bool(optional, default:True)

If set to True, the fingerprint will presented in the format of counter(not only 1 and 0) else, would be binary

CalculateEFG(mol)[source]¶

mol: rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

fp: list

following bits are always to be set as 1 or 0: bit0, bit1, bit2, bit59, bit60, bit61, bit62, bit209, bit218, bit544, bit545 It’s diffcult to counter them like others bits, because these bits contain “not”

scopy.fingerprint.estate module¶

Created on Wed Jul 17 10:15:43 2019

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

class scopy.fingerprint.estate.EStateFP(val)[source]¶

Bases: object

Atom-based calculation of LogP and MR using Crippen’s approach, 79 bits

Kier, Lemont Burwell, and Lowell H. Hall. Academic, 1999

val: bool(optional, default:True)

If set to True, the fingerprint will presented in the format of vaule of estate else, would be binary

CalculateEState(mol)[source]¶

mol: rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol.

fp: list

fingerprint in binary if val was false.

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints module¶

Created on Tue Jun 25 21:59:42 2019

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China， @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateDaylight(mols, minPath=1, maxPath=7, nBits=2048)[source]¶

a Daylight-like fingerprint based on hashing molecular subgraphs

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

minPath: int(optional, default:1)

minimum number of bonds to include in the subgraphs

maxPath: int(optional, default:7)

maximum number of bonds to include in the subgraphs

nBits: int(optional, default:2048)

number of bits in the fingerprint

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateECFP(mols, radius=2, nBits=1024)[source]¶

This family of fingerprints, better known as circular fingerprints, is built by applying the Morgan algorithm to a set of user-supplied atom invariants. 2^n bits

Rogers, David, and Mathew Hahn. J Chem Inf Model, 50(5), 742-754.

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

radius: int(optional, defailt: 2)

the radius of circle

nBits: int(optional, default:1024)

number of bits in the fingerprint

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateEFG(mols, counter=True)[source]¶

classification system termed “extended functional groups” (EFG), which are an extension of a set previously used by the CheckMol software, that covers in addition heterocyclic compound classes and periodic table groups. 583 bits

Salmina, Elena, Norbert Haider, and Igor Tetko. Molecules, 21(1), 1.

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

counter: bool(optional, default:True)

If set to True, the fingerprint will presented in the format of counter(not only 1 and 0) else, would be binary

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateEState(mols, val=True)[source]¶

Atom-based calculation of LogP and MR using Crippen’s approach, 79 bits

Kier, Lemont Burwell, and Lowell H. Hall. Academic, 1999

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

val: bool(optional, default:True)

If set to True, the fingerprint will presented in the format of vaule of estate else, would be binary

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateFCFP(mols, radius=2, nBits=1024)[source]¶

This family of fingerprints, better known as circular fingerprints, is built by applying the Morgan algorithm to a set of user-supplied atom invariants. 2^n bits

Rogers, David, and Mathew Hahn. J Chem Inf Model, 50(5), 742-754.

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

radius: int(optional, defailt: 2)

the radius of circle

nBits: int(optional, default:1024)

number of bits in the fingerprint

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateGhoseCrippen(mols, counter=True)[source]¶

Atom-based calculation of LogP and MR using Crippen’s approach, it’s 110 bits

Wildman, Scott A., and Gordon M. Crippen. JCICS, 39(5), 868-873.

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

counter: bool(optional, default:True)

If set to True, the fingerprint will presented in the format of counter(not only 1 and 0) else, would be binary

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.fingerprints.CalculateMACCS(mols)[source]¶

There is a SMARTS-based implementation of the 166 public MACCS keys. 166 bits

Using the 166 public keys implemented as SMARTS

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

The molecule(s) to be scanned

fps: numpy.ndarray

scopy.fingerprint.morgan module¶

Created on Mon Sep 2 17:31:14 2019

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China， @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

class scopy.fingerprint.morgan.Morgan(radius, nBits)[source]¶

Bases: object

This family of fingerprints, better known as circular fingerprints, is built by applying the Morgan algorithm to a set of user-supplied atom invariants. 2^n bits

Rogers, David, and Mathew Hahn. J Chem Inf Model, 50(5), 742-754.

radius: int(optional, defailt: 2)

the radius of circle

nBits: int(optional, default:1024)

number of bits in the fingerprint

useFeatures: bool(optional, default:False)

to control generate FCFP if True, else ECFP

CalculateECFP(mol)[source]¶

mols: Iterable object, each element is a rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol The molecule(s) to be scanned

fps: list

CalculateFCFP(mol)[source]¶

mols: rdkit.Chem.rdchem.Mol

fps: list

@Author: Zhi-Jiang Yang, Dong-Sheng Cao @Institution: CBDD Group, Xiangya School of Pharmaceutical Science, CSU, China @Homepage: http://www.scbdd.com @Mail: yzjkid9@gmail.com; oriental-cds@163.com @Blog: https://blog.moyule.me

Internal Use Only

generates SMARTS patterns for the keys, run once

scopy.fingerprint.pubchem.calcPubChemFingerAll(mol)[source]¶

Internal Use Only

Calculate PubChem Fingerprints

scopy.fingerprint.pubchem.calcPubChemFingerPart1(mol, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculate PubChem Fingerprints （1-115; 263-881)

Arguments

  • mol: the molecule to be fingerprinted

  • any extra keyword arguments are ignored

Returns

a _DataStructs.SparseBitVect_ containing the fingerprint.

>>> m = Chem.MolFromSmiles('CNO')
>>> bv = PubChemFingerPart1(m)
>>> tuple(bv.GetOnBits())
(24, 68, 69, 71, 93, 94, 102, 124, 131, 139, 151, 158, 160, 161, 164)
>>> bv = PubChemFingerPart1(Chem.MolFromSmiles('CCC'))
>>> tuple(bv.GetOnBits())
(74, 114, 149, 155, 160)
